title-group.article-title: Gauging the Emerging Plus-Size Footwear Market An Anthropometric Approach

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Juyeon Park is an assistant professor in the department of design and merchandising at the Colorado State University. Her scholarly interests include product development for human health and innovative uses of new technologies for apparel and footwear production.

abstract.p: In order to gauge the emerging needs for the plus-size footwear market, this study tested the following four hypotheses: 1) as BMI increases, foot morphology changes; 2) increased BMI influences consumers' footwear selection criteria; 3) increased BMI negatively affects consumers' footwear fit; and 4) increased BMI negatively affects consumers' satisfaction with the current footwear market. One hundred and twenty-one female college students were recruited from a large 4-year U.S. university, and only Caucasian data (n=99) were used for statistical analysis. Prior to 3D scanning, a short questionnaire was administered to assess the participants' footwear selection criteria and satisfaction with the current footwear offerings, as well as demographic information. Anthropometry of the participants' feet was measured, using a 3D foot scanner (INFOOT® by I-ware). Results showed that BMI positively affected the increase of anthropometric measurements; as BMI increased, the participants indicated significantly higher scores on shoe length and insole cushion and a lower score on fashion trendiness in the perceived importance of footwear selection criteria; they tended to wear improperly fitting shoes to accommodate wider and thicker feet; and they were significantly less satisfied with the current market than those with a lower BMI. Strong relationships in all four hypotheses were evident, and findings of this study urged the footwear manufacturing industry to recognize the unfulfilled niche market for the growing population of plus-size consumers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There are an estimated 1.46 billion overweight adults worldwide, and 502 million are considered obese (Finucane et al., 2011). Of particular concern is the United States, where the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey recently indicated that 33.8% of the overall population (32.2% men and 35.5% women) are obese, and the corresponding prevalence estimate for overweight and obesity combined is 68% of the population, including 72.3% of men and 64.1% of women (Flegal, Carroll, Ogden, & Curtin, 2010). Furthermore, a recent statistical study by Wang, Beydoun, Liang, Caballero, and Kumanyika (2008) projected that based on the longitudinal data of the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey collected from the 1970s to 2004, if this trend persists, by 2030, 86.3% of U.S. adults will be overweight or obese and 51.1% will be obese.

The rising rate of obesity and being overweight does not only increase the risk of adverse health conditions but also influences the current retail industry and evolving market demands, owing to consumers’ changing physical profiles (Farrigan & Pang, 2002; Finkelstein & Strombotne, 2010; Kim, Jolly, & Kim, 2007). In the context of apparel, plus-size products have been offered already on the consumer market. Since 2000, the plus-size women’s apparel industry has experienced a higher annual growth rate than the overall women’s apparel market (Connolly, 2008). In 2010, the U.S. market share of plus-size apparel was 17% of the overall women’s apparel market (Clifford, 2010), while the growing trend has remained steady (Connor, 2012).

The obesity epidemic and growth trend of plus-size apparel retailing may suggest that there needs to be a footwear market particularly for plus-size consumers. However, no scientific attempt has been made to gauge the market need. For this inquiry, the use of an anthropometric approach will determine whether and how the foot morphological changes, due to increased weight (body mass index [BMI] as a measure of obesity/overweight), influence consumers’ footwear selection criteria (i.e., fit, function, and form); how they affect consumers’ footwear fit; and how they influence consumers’ satisfaction with current footwear offerings. To this end, the four hypotheses below were formulated:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: As BMI increases, foot morphology changes.
Hypothesis 1a: As BMI increases, foot size changes.
Hypothesis 1b: As BMI increases, foot shape changes.
Hypothesis 2: Increased BMI influences consumers’ footwear selection criteria.
Hypothesis 3: Increased BMI negatively affects consumers’ footwear fit.
Hypothesis 4: Increased BMI negatively affects consumers’ satisfaction with the current footwear market.

sec.p: I argue that if all the hypotheses are supported, there is a potential need for a new niche footwear market for plus-size consumers. The rationale for the hypotheses is presented in the following literature review.

sec.title: The Effects of Obesity on Musculoskeletal Structure and Function
sec.p: Much research in biomechanics has studied the effect of obesity on musculoskeletal structure and function. Hills, Henning, Byrne, and Steele (2002) found that compared to participants of normal weight, obese individuals had a higher plantar pressure (i.e., the pressure exerted on the foot), and this increased plantar pressure was likely to result in wider forefoot areas (i.e., the front area of foot where a group of five long bones are located). Further, the authors (Hills, Henning, Byrne, & Steele, 2002) discovered that obese women tended to have higher pressure on their feet during static weight-bearing than did obese men, a difference that may be due to weaker foot ligaments in the female population. The contact area (i.e., the area of foot with the ground) is higher among the obese population (Hills et al., 2002; Mickle, Steele, & Munro, 2006). In other words, long-term mass increases associated with obesity were likely to flatten the medial longitudinal arch (i.e., the arch that runs along the inside of a human foot; Dowling & Steele, 2001). Scholars assert that obesity generates significantly higher dynamic pressure under the forefoot and obese populations thereby might be at an increased risk of developing clinical problems in this area of the foot (Hills et al., 2002; Mickle et al., 2006). Along these lines, Tsung, Zhang, Fan, and Boone (2003) investigated the changes in foot shape under different weight-bearing conditions. They determined that heavier weight-bearing significantly increased the contact area, foot length, foot width, and rear foot width, while it decreased average arch height and arch angle. In another study, Xiong, Goonetilleke, Witana, and Au (2008) also discovered that foot deformation can occur as a result of bearing extra weight. With this research, the authors confirmed that increased load from weight-bearing on the foot skeleton contributed to structural deformation and further found that the midfoot had relatively large changes in width and height when it was compared to the forefoot and rearfoot.

sec.title: Foot Morphology and Footwear
sec.p: Wearing footwear changes the way humans walk and how the body distributes weight, and poor-fitting shoes are known to cause foot deformities (Frey, Thompson, & Smith, 1995; Frey, Thompson, Smith, Sanders, & Horstman, 1993; Rajput & Abboud, 2004). According to Frey, Thompson, Smith, Sanders, and Horstman (1993), women are less likely to wear properly fitting shoes than men. This study found that women consistently wore shoes that were smaller than their feet, implicating shoes as the major cause of female foot problems. In a study of patients with diabetes mellitus (Reveal, Laughlin, Capecci, & Reeve, 2001), 30% of the diabetic patients wore shoes that were too narrow, despite the fact that 84% of the study participants self-reported that their shoes were comfortable; moreover, 81% of those with poor-fitting shoes were women. Interestingly, in comparison between obese and normal weight women, obese women tended to wear significantly larger shoe sizes than normal weight women (Gravante, Russo, Pomara, & Ridola, 2003). However, the reasons for the difference were not discussed in the study. Clinical reports suggest that poor-fitting shoes cause various foot problems such as blistering, chafing, black toes, bunions, pain, and tired feet (Hamill, Bates, Knutzen, & Kirkpatrick, 1989; Marr & Quine, 1993; Messier, Davies, Curl, Lowery, & Pack, 1991; Rossi, 1988). This causal relationship between footwear fit and clinical foot problems suggests support for the benefits of good footwear fit. Footwear fit is subjective and it is difficult to find the “right” fit (Au & Goonetilleke, 2007). Referring to the quote by Pliny the Elder that only the wearer knows where the shoe pinches, Rossi (1988) affirmed that the “perfect” shoe fit is impossible and the “correct” fit is highly improbable: “compromise” fit remains the only alternative. Researchers agree that if a shoe is too tight, the interface pressure produces tissue compression, making the shoe uncomfortable for the wearer. On the other hand, if a shoe is too loose, the wearer experiences slippage between the foot and the shoe, resulting in performance degradation and injury to soft tissue due to friction (Au & Goonetilleke, 2007).

sec.title: Evaluation of Footwear: Fit, Function, and Form
sec.p: Thanks to technological advances, footwear on the current market showcases various innovative features (e.g., abrasion resistance, moisture wicking, odor resistance, and wind proofing); likewise, styles and types of footwear are becoming diverse and abundant. Customized footwear is available for consumers who have foot problems, and orthopedic physicians provide quality services for those who are in need. Even though technological advancement and product personalization are thought to improve the functioning of footwear, some footwear is considered simply ornamental to enhance form rather than functionality to protect people’s feet.

Generally speaking, evaluation of footwear is based on fit, function, and form (Goonetilleke, 2003). In the case of bare feet, form follows function (Rossi, 2001), but for footwear products, fit is the most important property to govern function and form (Witana, Feng, & Goonetilleke, 2004). Traditionally, foot length has been considered the most or only critical measure for footwear fit (Goonetilleke, 2003), and it has been commonly measured by the Brannock device, typically found at retail stores. However, this popular method of foot length measurement often causes poor fitting, as most fit problems are generally about the “width” dimension or volume (Rossi, 2002). In recent years, three-dimensional (3D) scanning technology has been adopted to measure various dimensions of the human foot. The 3D scan data offer detailed information on the contours of the foot (Telfer & Woodburn, 2010). That is, 3D foot scanners can generate not only linear measurements (e.g., length and width) but also circumferential measurements (e.g., foot girth), in seconds (Telfer & Woodburn, 2010; Witana, Xiong, Zhao, & Goonetilleke, 2006). It should be noted that the skill level of the measurer and the instruments used might influence the measurement data, and the presence of dust particles on the scanner or high levels of ambient light might disturb sensitivity of the device (Bornaz, Lingua, & Rinaudo, 2002; Witana et al., 2006). However, the 3D scanning technology is considered the most reliable method available thus far for obtaining accurate foot measurements (Telfer & Woodburn, 2010).

Subjective evaluation of fit is as important as anthropometric measurements in determining footwear fit and comfort (Miller, Nigg, Liu, Stefanyshyn, & Nurse, 2000; Witana et al., 2004). In other words, individual preferences may influence fit perception, and thus subjective evaluations may provide information on perceived comfort and satisfaction (Telfer & Woodburn, 2010). This suggests that objective and subjective variables should both be taken into account in fit evaluation. The need for both subjective and objective assessments also corresponds to fit evaluation for apparel products. As scholars have asserted (Ashdown & O’Connell, 2006; Zhang, Zhang, & Xiao, 2011), subjective perception testing is often used in apparel fit assessment, since human senses sometimes determine complex stimuli more effectively than any machine.

In addition to fit and comfort, consumers demand quality and reliable products that correspond to their specific needs and standards in functionality and aesthetic tastes (Piller & Müller, 2004). For example, for many women, shoes are a main fashion accessory that complements their outfits; such selection preference toward style makes it comparatively more difficult for them to find comfortable shoes because their choice is dictated by fashion trends rather than by biomechanical suggestions (Luximon, Goonetillek, & Tsui, 2003). On the other hand, for some consumers, especially those who need to be on their feet for long periods and/or who are less conscious of fashion and style, functional elements such as cushioning and arch support are considered much more important than form (Goonetilleke, 2003). These consumers are willing to purchase such footwear products at the expense of fashion and style, or possibly they do not even care about how they look. Individual differences in perceived level of functionality and style (i.e., form) also play an important role in the evaluation of footwear. For instance, a certain level of midsole cushioning that is considered “good” to one person may feel uncomfortable to another (i.e., the wearer’s weight can have a significant impact on subjective perceptions; Goonetilleke, 1999). Therefore, in this study, subjective ratings of footwear evaluation, as well as anthropometric foot measurements, were both considered in order to test the study hypotheses.

sec.title: Sample Selection and Recruitment Strategy
sec.p: Exploratory in nature, a convenience sample of U.S. female college students was recruited. Although this sampling method has inherent potential biases, this sample group, which is homogeneous in age, gender, status, and geographical location, was expected to reduce possible sampling errors to some extent (Calder, Phillips, & Tybout, 1981). Only participants who met the following inclusion criteria—U.S. female college students aged between 18 and 29—were invited to this study.

Published prevalence data were investigated further to determine the obesity rate of the particular demographic group selected for the present study. Data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey collected from 2005 to 2008 (Ogden, Lamb, Carroll, & Flegan, 2010) provided evidence that education negatively influences obesity prevalence among the U.S. female population; that is, significantly fewer U.S. female adults with a college degree (23.4%) were obese than those with less than a high school education (42.1%). Another national survey (Lowry et al., 2000) of 4,838 U.S. female college students provided additional concrete evidence, indicating that 17.9% of study participants were overweight and 12.0% were obese. Lowry et al.’s (2000) study also indicated the “age” factor on obesity prevalence: The prevalence rate among female college students (17.9%) was much lower than that of college-educated female adults of all ages (23.4%). This epidemic trend signifies that the prevalence of obesity increases as age increases when both gender and education level are controlled. In sum, the combined obesity and overweight rate estimated for the study population was approximately 30%.

One hundred and twenty-one female college students were recruited from a large 4-year university located in the Midwest region of the United States; for further minimization of sampling errors, only Caucasian data (n = 99, 81.8%) were used for analysis. The percentage of the Caucasian population in the particular state where data collection occurred is 81.3%, according to the 2010 U.S. Census (United State Census Bureau, 2011), which therefore corresponded well with the data of this study. Multiple recruitment strategies were employed in this study, which included disseminating recruitment flyers across the campus, in-class announcements, and e-blasts to students whose demographic profiles met the inclusion criteria for study participation. Overall, participants were in favor of participating in the study; however, some exhibited hesitation to actually be involved in the study, due to unfamiliarity with the 3D foot scanning technology. Therefore, to increase the number of participants, once the initial cohort was identified and data were collected, further recruitment was pursued among acquaintances of the participants who already had experience with the foot scanner. As a result, 80 participants were recruited from the first recruitment effort and an additional 41 participants were recruited from the second effort via respondent-driven sampling. The participants represented diverse academic majors of the university. After recruitment efforts were made across the campus, those students who wanted to participate in this study voluntarily contacted the researcher by their preferred communication method, either phone or e-mail, for scheduling. The researcher also followed up with the potential participants who signed up when the researcher was making the in-class announcement for recruitment.

sec.title: Research Instruments and Procedure
sec.p: Data collection took place between 12 p.m. and 2 p.m., when the participants were most active. This narrow time window for data collection was used to avoid potential effects of external variables on the foot size (e.g., swelling), due to measurement time of day. A short questionnaire was administered to each participant prior to 3D scanning in order to measure the participant’s subjective evaluation of footwear. The questionnaire was developed to assess footwear selection criteria and consumer satisfaction with the current footwear offerings, along with collecting the participant’s background information such as the most frequently worn footwear size (length and width), self-reported height/weight, and current academic major/level. As for footwear selection criteria, nine variables that reflected the three evaluation categories of footwear—fit, function, and form—were measured by a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = not important at all, 7 = extremely important). Participants were also asked to rate their satisfaction levels with the current footwear market using a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). Four variables were measured in this section, including the participant’s satisfaction with (a) footwear sizes, (b) footwear styles, (c) footwear product variety available on the current market, and (d) overall satisfaction with footwear shopping.

A 3D foot scanner (INFOOT® by I-ware) was used to measure the 3D of both sides of the participant’s feet (right and left). Using two noninvasive laser beams across the foot, the 3D device captured 14 landmark measurements (Figures 1 and 2) in 5 s/foot. The measurements included foot length, ball girth circumference, foot breadth, instep circumference, heel breadth, instep length, fibulare instep length, height of top of ball girth, height of instep, height of navicular, toe #1 angle, and toe #5 angle, arch length, and angle of heel bone. The total duration of data collection per participant took approximately 10–15 min from survey completion to 3D measurement. Before the actual data collection, participants were provided a consent form to read and sign (IRB 09-865H).

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Statistical Package for the Social Sciences 18.0 and Amos 17.0 were used to perform descriptive statistics, reliability tests, correlation analysis, principal component analysis (PCA), regression analyses, and path analysis. Each participant was assigned an ID number in order to ensure confidentiality of the participant’s information. The reliability of the survey questions and anthropometric measurement variables was tested to measure internal consistency of the constructs. The Cronbach’s α values of the study variables confirmed that the reliability was satisfactory at a 95% confidence level: (a) the α value of the anthropometric measurement variables for 3D foot scanning was .766; (b) the α value of the rating questions on consumer footwear selection criteria was .714; and (c) the α value of the survey questions on consumer satisfaction was .889. The reliability tests showed that deletion of any single variable did not positively impact the overall reliability of the data, which indicates that all the constructs were necessary and reliable.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Data were collected in fall 2009–spring 2010 and spring–summer 2011. The average age of the participants was 21.22 (SD = 2.184). The average self-reported height was 166.53 cm (5.46 ft in imperial measurement, SD = 7.71), and the average self-reported weight was 64.77 kg (145 lb in imperial measurement, SD = 14.01). The calculation of BMI, defined as a measure of body fat based on height and weight, was used to determine the obesity/overweight rate of the participants, based on the participants’ self-reported height and weight: A BMI measure of 30 or greater qualifies an individual as obese; 25.0–29.9 is overweight; scores between 18 and 24.9 are considered normal weight; and less than 18 is underweight (Flegal et al., 2010). The average BMI score of the participants was 23.31 (SD = 4.22) or normal weight. Sixty-eight percent of the participants (n = 66) were identified as normal weight, while 22.7% (n = 22) were overweight, 7.2% (n = 7) obese, and 2.11% (n = 2) underweight. The overweight and obesity combined prevalence in this study was 29.9%, which corresponded well to the combined prevalence rate of Lowry et al.’s (2000) study. However, the overweight rate of this study (22.7%) was comparatively higher, and the obesity rate (7.2%) was lower than those (17.9% and 12.0% respectively) of the Lowry et al.’s study. These differences presumably reflect the overall state-to-state obesity prevalence trends in the United States, which suggests a further investigation of cross-state comparisons in a follow-up study.

sec.title: Anthropometric Measurement
sec.p: Simple pairwise Pearson correlation analysis determined that the following six measurement variables, out of 14 landmarks measured by a 3D foot scanner, were strongly correlated with BMI: foot length (r = .295, df = 97, p = .003), ball girth circumference (r = .357, df = 97, p = .000), foot breadth (r = .474, df = 97, p = .000), heel breadth (r = .602, df = 97, p = .000), instep length (r = .210, df = 97, p = .039), and height of top of ball girth (r = .500, df = 97, p = .000). In order to determine the relationships between BMI and each correlated foot measurement, simple linear regression analyses were performed at a 95% confidence level. Prior to regression analyses, PCA combined the participant’s left and right scan data into a single factor (i.e., the highly correlated variables of foot measurements for both feet were summarized into a single data set, and this new set of data represented a linear combination of the two original variables of feet). Simple linear regression analyses determined regression coefficients of all six variables were positive and the critical significance levels were less than .05, confirming that the relationships between BMI and the six variables were statistically significant. A summary of regression data is presented in Table 1. These findings indicate that participants with a higher BMI tended to have longer and wider feet with higher volume in their forefoot. Namely, the anthropometric data elucidate that increased BMI (i.e., the indicator of obesity/overweight) influences foot size and shape, which supports Hypothesis 1a and Hypothesis 1b.

sec.p: However, relatively low R2 scores of the measurement variables, especially the lengthwise variables such as foot length and instep length, should be noted (refer to Table 1). Multivariate linear regression analyses were additionally conducted to examine whether other variables, such as height, contribute to the R2 scores. Along with BMI, when self-reported height information was added to the data set as an additional independent variable, R2 scores of the two lengthwise dependent variables, foot length and instep length, significantly increased from .087 to .602 and from .044 to .568 respectively. It is thus possible to infer that height plays a major role in determining one’s overall foot and instep length, while BMI also positively affects the lengthwise measurements. Further investigation is necessary to confirm this finding and identify additional determinant factors (e.g., ethnicity) for the variation in human foot length, besides height and BMI.

sec.title: Footwear Selection Criteria
sec.p: Simple linear regression analyses revealed linear relationships of BMI with nine variables for footwear selection. Among the nine variables, three variables—shoe length (p = .001, F = 10.997, df = 1, B = .129, R2 = .104); fashion trendiness (p = .042, F = 4.244, df = 1, B = −.060, R2 = .043); and insole cushion (p = .030, F = 4.839, df = 1, B = .068, R2 = .048)—showed significant linear relationships with BMI at a 95% confidence level. These findings suggest that as BMI increased, the participants valued more on shoe length (fit) and insole cushion (function), whereas fashion trendiness (style) became less important. That is, for those with a higher BMI, when they go shopping, they prioritize the fit and functional components of footwear over style. Hypothesis 2 was thus supported, which posited that increased BMI influences consumers’ footwear selection criteria. This result may signify that plus-size consumers undergo a negotiation process among the three footwear selection criteria to compromise footwear style (i.e., form) for a better fit and functionality.

sec.title: Footwear Fit and Size Disparity
sec.p: In order to examine the overall relationship between BMI and footwear fit, footwear size disparity, defined in this study as the difference between the participant’s footwear size most frequently worn and the 3D scanner-calculated foot size, was calculated in the U.S. shoe size system (for detailed information on the size system, refer to Tyrrell & Carter, 2009, pp. 80–84). The footwear size disparity was used in this study as a parameter for assessment of footwear fit: the higher the disparity than the average range, the poorer footwear fit. The disparity range of this study was from −.5 to 2.0 and the average was .758 (SD = .517), which indicates that on average the participants wore shoes .758 larger than the 3D scanner-calculated foot size. That is to say, if a participant’s actual foot size was calculated by a 3D foot scanner as a 7, this individual would wear either shoe size 7.5 or 8 in the U.S. size system, depending on the wearer’s personal preference and feeling of subjective comfort.

Simple linear regression analysis showed a significant linear relationship between BMI and footwear size disparity (p = .000, F = 19.177, df = 1, B = .049, R2 = .168). This result suggests that as BMI increased, participants tended to wear larger size shoes (i.e., ill-fitting shoes) than their actual suggested shoe size. This finding supports Hypothesis 3, which proposed that increased BMI negatively affects consumers’ footwear fit. In conjunction with the aforementioned anthropometric findings, it might be possible to infer that participants with a higher BMI would likely wear larger shoes than those with a lower BMI, which would accommodate the proportionally increased width and volume of their feet due to increased BMI. This causal relationship will be further evaluated with a path analysis later in the article.

sec.title: Consumer Satisfaction With Current Footwear Market
sec.p: Consumer satisfaction with the current footwear market was measured by the following four variables on a 7-point Likert-type scale: availability of right footwear sizes (e.g., I have always been successful in finding right size shoes for me. χˉ = 4.97); availability of right styles (e.g., I have always been successful in finding right style shoes for me. χˉ = 4.68); availability of product variety (e.g., I am satisfied with the shoe options on the current market. χˉ = 4.55); and overall satisfaction with footwear shopping (e.g., footwear shopping is enjoyable. χˉ = 5.36). The study participants responded most positively on overall satisfaction with footwear shopping and least positively on satisfaction with available footwear product variety.

Hypothesis 4 was supported by simple linear regression analysis. Negative linear relationships were found between BMI and all four satisfaction variables at a 95% confidence level, including availability of right sizes (p = .001, F = 10.866, df = 1. B = −.133, R2 = .103); right styles (p = .001, F = 12.606, df = 1, B = −140, R2 = .117); product variety (p = .014, F = 6.330, df = 1, B = .−108, R2 = .062); and overall satisfaction with footwear shopping (p = .000, F = 18.701, df = 1, B = −.177, R2 = .166). Regression coefficients indicate that BMI negatively affects consumer satisfaction with the current footwear market. That is, as BMI increased, participants tended to be, to a significant degree, less satisfied with footwear sizes, styles, and product variety available on the current market; presumably the lower satisfaction level influenced overall footwear shopping experience.

sec.title: Path Analysis
sec.p: A path analysis, using AMOS 17.0, was performed to test the overall relationships among BMI (X1), foot length (X2), foot width (X3), footwear size disparity (X4), and consumer satisfaction (X5). Due to concern about the sample size, the model was simplified to reduce the number of unobserved variables. Although there is no absolute standard for sample size in path analysis, commonly adopted is Kline’s (1998) recommendation based on path model complexity: a desirable sample size is at least 5 times of the number of parameters. In this particular path model, the number of distinct parameters to be estimated is 18, thus the minimum sample size is 90. Because the study’s sample size was 99 participants, the sample size of this study is acceptable. Goodness-of-fit indices, in addition to the χ2 statistic (χ2 = 7.629, df = 2), indicated a good fit with the observed data (p > .05, NFI = .943, root mean square error of approximation = .069, CFI = .953). Figure 3 shows the summation of the path analysis results. The path analysis diagram (Figure 3) illustrates that BMI significantly affects foot width, which in turn directly influences footwear size disparity at a 99.9% confidence level and consumer satisfaction at a 95% confidence level.

sec.p: BMI had positive direct effects on foot length (.075) and foot width (.069) and an indirect effect on foot width through foot length (.043). BMI also had a negative direct effect on satisfaction (−.049) and a negative indirect effect on satisfaction through foot width (−.033). Foot length had a positive direct effect on foot width (.569) and a positive indirect effect on footwear size disparity through foot width (.135). The direct effect of foot length on footwear size disparity was not significant. Foot width showed a negative direct effect on satisfaction (−.252), but the indirect effect through footwear size disparity was insignificant. Total, direct, and indirect effects of the path analysis are presented in Table 2.

sec.p: The path analysis showed that BMI was positively related with the increase of foot measurements, and enlarged foot width was negatively related with consumers’ satisfaction with the current footwear market. In addition, BMI affected foot width which in turn noticeably affected footwear size disparity; that is, BMI led to wider feet which in turn led to wearing a much larger shoe sizes than the average range.

sec.title: Conclusion and Implications
sec.p: Four study hypotheses were examined in this study. For the first hypothesis, six foot measurement variables (foot length, ball girth circumference, foot breadth, heel breath, instep length, and height of top of ball girth) showed significant correlations with BMI. As BMI increased, the sizes of the six variables increased. BMI positively affected the increase of the six anthropometric measurements, which influences the size and shape of the participants’ feet.

Evidence, gleaned from testing the second hypothesis, showed that increased BMI influenced the participants’ footwear selection criteria. Participants with a higher BMI showed significantly higher scores on shoe length and insole cushion and a lower score on fashion trendiness in the perceived importance of various footwear selection criteria. From this evidence, we might infer that obese/overweight young, female consumers tend to consider fit and function more so than they do style. In addition, changes in foot morphology led to increased BMI which in turn negatively influenced the participants’ footwear fit. This supported the third hypothesis. The result attests to the notion that as BMI increased, the participants tended to wear larger shoes (i.e., improperly fitting shoes) than the average range, to accommodate wider and thicker feet. For the fourth hypothesis, which set out to examine consumer satisfaction with the current footwear market, results indicate that participants with a higher BMI showed significantly less satisfaction with the current market than those with lower BMIs. This may suggest that the foot morphological changes due to increased BMI negatively influence consumer satisfaction with the current offerings available on the footwear market.

Returning to the morphology of the foot and the effect of BMI, the fact that the height of top of ball girth is higher as the rate of BMI increases implies that the increased BMI does not flatten the entire foot area. While this study confirmed previous research findings that the higher plantar pressure caused by the heavier weight compresses the medial longitudinal arch and heel breadth (Dowling & Steele, 2001; Dowling, Steele, & Baur, 2001; Gravante et al., 2003; Riddiford-Harland, Steele, & Storlien, 2000), the increased weight does not compress the forefoot area but rather adds more volume in that area. This contradiction suggests that there could be great benefits in further research on foot morphological changes in segmented foot areas (forefoot, midfoot, and rearfoot) by the increased weight.

Path analysis results illustrated the causal relationships among BMI, foot length, foot width, footwear size disparity, and consumer satisfaction. The results showed that BMI positively influenced foot length and width and negatively affected consumer satisfaction with the footwear market. Path coefficients indicated that foot width was a significant predictor of footwear size disparity, but foot length was not. This finding can be interpreted to suggest that when one has wider feet, he or she tends to wear larger shoes than the average range; however, this does not apply to longer feet. This result shows that in order to increase overall market satisfaction of consumers and to be inclusive of those who have wider feet such as the obese population, foot width should be more commonly taken into account in commercial footwear fitting at retail stores.

Further research needs to be conducted using varied populations with different demographic profiles and larger sample sizes. Although data of this exploratory study represented the combined obesity and overweight prevalence rate of U.S. female college students, generalizability of the study findings was limited by the use of a convenient sample of female college students in a single geographical region. In addition, the relatively small number of study participants (n = 99) consequently yielded the small sample size of obese/overweight participants (n = 29). In order to address the concern with the unequal sample sizes between normal weight and obese/overweight participants, regression analyses were performed to test the hypotheses in this study. The choice of statistical analyses was appropriate, since BMI is a continuous variable. However, a larger sample size of the U.S. population is recommended on a random sample to increase the validity of the study findings. Studies of participants with different demographic profiles such as males and older females are desirable.

In the contemporary consumer market, particularly for female consumers, footwear is not just performance gear but a symbolic fashion item that finishes one’s look and reflects the primacy of her individual taste. Therefore, aesthetics has its own value, and consumers pursue both beauty and pleasure from their consumption (Postrel, 2003). However, such aesthetic pleasure does not come without meaningful substantive ramifications—in the case of footwear, fit, and function. Findings of this study strongly suggest that in spite of young female consumers’ high interests in style and looks, the unsatisfactory fit and functionality of currently available footwear in the market, particularly for plus-size consumers, hinder them from looking for aesthetic pleasure. Although consumer satisfaction was measured as an indicator for the emerging market, further research is desired to determine more detailed information on particular consumer needs and wants for the plus-size footwear market. In conclusion, I urge the footwear manufacturing industry to recognize the unfulfilled niche market for the growing population of plus-size consumers.
